learning_outcomes.description: Identify key standards and principles that guide and underpin safe, high quality healthcare delivery.
Identify key professional, legal and ethical frameworks that underpin practice.
Work in a health professional team to apply principles of professional frameworks to professional practice.
Critically examine tensions in applying legal and ethical frameworks in professional practice and for culturally diverse groups including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations.

assessments.due_date:
9/03/2026 - 25/03/2026

Quiz 1 - Opens Monday 9/3/26 at 9am, closes Wednesday 11/3/26 at 1pm.

Quiz 2 - Opens Monday 23/3/26 at 9am, closes Wednesday 25/3/26 at 1pm.
assessments.task_description:
The aim of this assessment is for students to identify key components of professional, legal and ethical frameworks that guide safe, high quality healthcare delivery and nursing practice.

This assessment consists of two (2) online quizzes, each weighted at 10%. For each quiz, students will complete multiple choice and short answer questions randomly selected from a test bank of questions.

Students are to refer to the course Blackboard site Assessment tab for additional details.Â
assessments.submission_guidelines: Quiz responses are directly submitted to Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The aim of this assessment is for students to demonstrate integrated analysis of legal, ethical, and cultural safety frameworks through examination of a complex nursing practice scenario.

This is a structured essay of 1500 words that consists of six sections:

  • Section 1: Introduction identifying key legal and ethical issues in the scenario
  • Section 2: Analysis of consent, capacity, and restrictive practices
  • Section 3: Analysis of accountability, documentation, and open disclosure
  • Section 4: Analysis of cultural safety and family communication
  • Section 5: Evidence-based nursing response and recommendations
  • Section 6: Conclusion synthesising legal and ethical tensions

Students must analyse the provided scenario by applying state-specific legislation, professional codes, and ethical frameworks to propose practical nursing actions that demonstrate culturally safe, legally compliant, and ethically sound practice.

A word count that is within 10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. A word count that is outside these 10% will be penalised through a reduction of 10% of the total mark available for the assessment.

Students are to refer to the course Blackboard site Assessment tab for additional details.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students are required to submit their work as a word document file only to the TURNITIN submission portal located on Blackboard. Alternate file types (e.g PDF) must not be submitted and will not be graded.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Paired project - legal and ethical issues in practice
assessments.due_date:
Written summaries Monday 25/5/2026 at 1pm.

Individual in-person interactive oral assessment during scheduled end of semester exam period.
assessments.task_description:
The aim of this assessment is for students to demonstrate deep understanding of legal OR ethical principles through preparation and application to nursing practice scenarios.

This assessment consists of two parts:

  • Part A (20%): Paired preparation of written summaries for two (2) nursing practice scenarios. Working with a partner, one student focuses on legal issues while the other focuses on ethical issues. Each student prepares summaries identifying conflicts, relevant principles, evidence-based strategies, and research process reflections (800 words total, submitted individually).
  • Part B (25%): Individual interactive oral assessment where students receive one scenario randomly selected by the marker from the prepared summaries. Each student has six (6) minutes to write notes recalling the conflict, two relevant principles, and the first nursing action a nurse should take. Each student will then have five (5) minutes to respond to three (3) questions from the marker simulating collaboration with colleagues in clinical decision making.


Students are to refer to the course Blackboard site Assessment tab for additional details.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students are required to submit their work as a word document file only to the TURNITIN submission portal located on Blackboard. Alternate file types (e.g PDF) must not be submitted and will not be graded.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 8(23 Feb - 26 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

There will be three (3) lectures throughout the semester. These interactive sessions apply and explore the online module content in real time. Lectures will also provide activities to guide and support you with course assessment. Your lecture dates and times are found on your timetable.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

Module 1 (weeks 1-4): What frameworks govern nursing practice?

Module 2 (weeks 5-8): What principles are found in the frameworks?

Module 3 (weeks 9-12): Not everything is black and white: Applying frameworks in practice

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 12(02 Mar - 24 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Inquiry Based Learning

Inquiry Based Learning (IBL) Workshops (TUT 1 and TUT2): There will be four (4) face-to-face and one (1) online IBL workshops throughout the semester. Refer to your timetable for relevant dates and times. Resources and details for each workshop can be found in "Learning Resources" tab > "UQ Extend course content link on the Learn.UQ Blackboard site for this course. Note: your selected workshop date and time will determine your pair allocation for assessment 3.
